instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00138: What is 820-00138? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
threads.message: This one is really strange. I got <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> which is working perfectly fine except right side USB port, which is working partially - it recognises external flash drives, USB mouses or even boots and works from external drive OS, but the problem is, that it doesn't recognise iPhone at all. AMP meter shows 5V but 0,03-0,05A of drain when phone is connected (it won't recognise phone with AMP meter disconnected too). If I connect 2,5" HDD over adapter, it takes 0,79A, then drops to 0,12A and doesn't recognise it. But if I connect the same drive without AMP meter drive is recognised and works OK. I have already replaced I/O board and both flex cables, but with no success. Connectors on motherboard look perfect, no corrossion or damage. Other side USB port works completely fine with all devices I connect to it. I thought it could be power problem, but it keeps 5V stable on board. Maybe it's PCH protocol problem?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
threads.message: It raises to 3,3V when computer turns on and stays like that all the time, no matter if I connect devices to USB port.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
threads.message:
So USB overcurrent is not triggered.
Can you check with similar machine the behaviour of right USB port?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
threads.message: On the similar machine right port works normally, it detects and charges iPhone (or other phones). <SIGNAL>USB_EXTB_OC_L</SIGNAL> line is stable 3,3V and doesn't change if I connect USB device.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
threads.message:
Check <CAPACITOR>C9501</CAPACITOR>/02.
Also check diode mode to ground on <SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB</SIGNAL> data lines.
Maybe right port only works in USB 2.0 mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00138</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> I/O board USB problem
threads.message:
<CAPACITOR>C9501</CAPACITOR>/02 are not shorted. Pin 2 on both caps reads OL, pin 1 reads 0,335V in diode mode. Traces are OK too.

data lines diode mode readings (I/O board disconnected):

<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2D_N</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2D_P</SIGNAL> - OL

<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2R_N</SIGNAL> - 0,323
<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2R_P</SIGNAL> - 0,323

<SIGNAL>USB_EXTB_N</SIGNAL> - 0,367
<SIGNAL>USB_EXTB_P</SIGNAL> - 0,369

data lines diode mode readings (I/O board connected):

<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2D_N</SIGNAL> - OL
<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2D_P</SIGNAL> - OL

<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2R_N</SIGNAL> - 0,323
<SIGNAL>USB3_EXTB_R2R_P</SIGNAL> - 0,323

<SIGNAL>USB_EXTB_N</SIGNAL> - 0,367
<SIGNAL>USB_EXTB_P</SIGNAL> - 0,364
